channel.title: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions
channel.description:
I've been working with BCEL lately and alot of old questions are answered along with the uprise of new ones. I've worked out how to change around simple classes; even a few ones such as text in the client etc etc. I'm trying to commit alot of this to memory but as I get further along all of these new questions are arising. For starters..
-Can explain the whole concept of the "entity" and how it's important in runescape client hacking, this is definetley a prolific question that I'd love to have answered -Could you offer a few tips on how to quickly locate and recognize pattern within the client code; I know there's alot of people who can do this very quickly. Anything will help
Thanks a million, Speedster239...
You can add my msn aswell: speedster239@1337cheat.com

item.title: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

Thank you very much BAsh(CntLgn), yakman and White Castle. You’ve helped alot.

Read full topic
item.source: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions

item.title: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

yakman:

i think peoples problem these days is trying to learn client hacking and bytecode all at the same time. my advice to new people would be to first get yourself a deob and mess around with it for a few updates, then try bytecode a bit.

It might help if we do some of the work, ie build a deobber and renamer and then let them improve each “module” as it were. The problem is that then there is no incentive to build something better because you already have the output. I really don’t see a solution except slow development by a few obsessed people (ie. me).

Read full topic
item.source: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions

item.title: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

BAsh(CntLgn):

As it is said in another thread: this will eventually destroy the community either due to shear inactivity or new members unable to learn because the information is not available.

im not so sure about this, when i started learning about updating and stuff, there was never any of this information ether, but i think its quite obvious in some way, like look for this method/field of this type/number of fields or whatever.

i think peoples problem these days is trying to learn client hacking and bytecode all at the same time. my advice to new people would be to first get yourself a deob and mess around with it for a few updates, then try bytecode a bit.

Read full topic
item.source: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions

item.title: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

There are many ways to pattern match. Basically any structure/feature/property of the client is fair game to a pattern matcher. What you are looking for are things that don’t change from client version to version but do change from class to class, method to method, instruction to instruction, etc… depending on the scale you are looking for.

Unfortunately except for primitive hooks you are not going to find much information on these forums. That said it might give you a few ideas. The reason for this secrecy is the fear that by revealing what you hook that there is a possibility that jagex will find out and build a obfuscater specifically to break it. As it is said in another thread: this will eventually destroy the community either due to shear inactivity or new members unable to learn because the information is not available.

Read full topic
item.source: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions

item.title: [BCEL] - Help me cover a few arising questions
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

An ‘Entity’ is what some people have dubbed the abstract superclass of the ‘Player’ and the ‘NPC’ classes.

Your second question is rather hard to answer… what kind of patterns would you like to identify?

Read full topic
